Master the hold
Find the end hold stairs and clear all the secret rooms

I Woke Up and Just Hated Everything
Yes, you should be so destructive

Clear 7 infested, non-secret rooms without turning your sword.

Beethro Budkin, fifth-generation professional dungeon exterminator, was hired by King Dugan to clear the king's multi-level dungeon of a large monster infestation.
Beethro charges by the room, and as a professional, he is contract-bound to clear all the monsters from each and every room in the dungeon to get paid.
The only weapon Beethro needs to do his job is a Really Big Sword, which will defeat almost any monster in a single hit.

-----

"I hope you're not going to charge me for the top level. I already have that cleaned up. Well, mostly." -King Dugan
Beethro's a bit rusty, but the next level should get him in good chopping form.
"Hmm..." pondered Beethro. "So far, I see mostly roaches down here. This looks like a cake job."
"I wish I had some more of those mimics down here with me!" said Beethro. "It would go a lot quicker."
Beethro came back to finish the proper smiting business he was hired to do.

Beethro descended the stairs, only to find himself in an uncharted corridor...

He won't get paid for clean-up here, but his professional honor urges him onward.

Beethro descended the stairs, only to find himself in an uncharted corridor...

He won't get paid for clean-up here, but his professional honor urges him onward.

Beethro descended the stairs, only to find himself in an uncharted corridor...

He won't get paid for clean-up here, but his professional honor urges him onward.
Use numerical keyboard or %keymap.all_moves% to move around. Keys can be remapped from within the pause menu (escape).
To reference the controls anytime you wish, hit `Escape`, click `Get General Help` and go to `How to Play`.

This yellow door will serve its purpose later.

For now just continue west.
You can move diagonally even through very narrow corridors.
Strike the orb with your sword to open doors in the room.
Some orbs toggle the yellow doors between their open and closed states.
Instead of toggling a yellow door, an orb might always open or close it.
You can find out what an orb does by clicking it with your mouse. Differently colored highlighted doors indicate the different effects.
Blue gates open once you conquer all the required rooms on a given level (floor).
Required rooms are marked with a red background on the minimap.
Current speech and hovering text can be skipped with the space bar.
Once you leave a room cleared of all monsters, it will be marked as conquered.
On the minimap, conquered rooms are marked with white as opposed to the unconquered ones which are red.
Conquer all the required rooms to open your way to the next level.
Force arrows block both Beethro's and monsters' movement in the opposite direction.
Green gates open once you clear a room of all monsters.
Most monsters when moving onto a corner diagonally will slide vertically if possible.
Observe how the southern roach behaves when it tries to move onto a corner diagonally.
This game is completely deterministic - there is no random or unpredictable behavior.

Touching a checkpoint 'X' allows you to rewind to when you last stepped on it.
Hit `%keymap.restart%` to restart the room or go back to the last checkpoint you have touched.

Look out!  It's dangerous here.

If you make a mistake, hit `%keymap.undo%` to undo a move.
Remember that you can click an orb with the mouse to see what doors it affects.
You can also undo (and restart) when the death animation is playing!
Secret walls blend with the regular ones much better though.
Broken and secret walls can be damaged by your sword.
A fine swordsman can defeat all the roaches without using the southern nook for cover!
So don't miss the ones in the corner when you come back.
These stairs lead to the next level. Beware of what you will meet there...
The secrets don't have to be conquered in one playthrough for the hold to be Mastered.
Place yourself on the green floor and make sure the roach stands on the sand tile directly north of you...
Follow the sandy path to learn the backswipe technique! Remember about diagonal movement and don't turn your sword.
Repeat to analyze the backswipe. Master this technique, for it will prove crucial in your further endeavors.
Place yourself on the green floor and make sure the roach stands on the sand tile directly south of you...
Sorry'ir, we'r nyet goin' to fin'sh ze buildn' wiz ze grand' roche'z runin' wild!
Emergency exit is out of commission.
Please keep the greenhouse doors closed.
Please keep the greenhouse doors closed.
You may wish to clear the rooms to the north first.
Don't do it! It's obvious what will happen!
Good timing makes things a lot easier.
You can prevent yourself from accidentally leaving a room by hitting the '%keymap.lock%' key on your keyboard.
A small lock on the minimap indicates that a room is locked.
Roach queens always run away from Beethro; this behavior can be used to manipulate them.
Did you know that you can hold Shift while performing any action to automatically follow it with its inverse?
`%keymap.battle%` will perform the inverse of the last action! Good for quickly cleaning up a horde of monsters.
Roach queens spawn roach eggs every 30 turns (the turn after the spawn counter becomes red).
Eggs will hatch into fully grown-up roaches 5 turns after being spawned.
You can use Shift+Wait to skip until the next spawn.
If you don't know it yet, Queens move away from you and don't lay eggs on open yellow gates.
Also, if a queen is moving on the spawn turn, no egg will appear on the tile she has just moved from.
Eggs will never appear on trapdoors, arrows, or opened yellow gates.
Observe carefully what happens on the spawn turn.
These pink-purple tiles are trapdoors and they fall if you or a mimic step off them.

Hint:

Think hard to develop the very useful BACKSWIPING technique -- good for when there's a monster on each side of you!

Hint:

You don't need the mimic's help to fight the roaches at the entrance.
If you have good style, all 9 mimics will be lined up to the right of you.
This is a master wall. It won't open until you conquer the hold and also all of its secrets.
In the original "King Dugan's Dungeon", this was a warp room which allowed you to skip a level or two.
You might find it useful that Shift+Wait waits until the next spawn.
On this level you'll encounter evil eyes. Once you step in their line of sight they'll wake up and chase you like roaches do.
With the invisible potion they can't see you, but they can still smell you if you get close.
Here is something that I will tell you--whenever you see long and laborious paths, you should look for shortcuts.
Turn back! Did you know that in just the last year, dungeon-related deaths were up by 32 percent?

Face the facts--dungeon exploration is NOT safe, especially when combined with intoxicants.
-PADD (Parents Against Dungeon Deaths)
It is possible to get to this passage without reentering the room after you've conquered it.
The Eight Gates of Bill--a formidable puzzle indeed. It used to be a lot harder, but I can now inspect the orbs to see what they do.
Such a long walk. It almost seems unnecessary.
After stepping on a mimic potion, use your mouse or wait key to choose the tile where you want to place the mimic.

All of the prisoners have been eaten by dungeon roaches, and I'm next! You can't pay me enough to work this job. I'm outta here!

-Prison Warden
I must warn you about mimics. They are neither your friends nor your enemies--they simply like to move exactly as you do. Don't turn your back on them.
After stepping on a mimic potion, use your mouse or wait key to choose the tile where you want to place the mimic.
Roach Queens will be killed once you step on the checkpoint in the right-top corner.
Here is a small reward! Kill all the eyes without stepping on the brown grass.
This scroll used to urge you to play more episodes on CaravelGames.com but with this release they all are bundled into one game so you can just Change Episode from the title screen.
I sincerely congratulate you and invite you to continue your journey.
That's it. By now you have completed everything there is in this game. There may only be a couple of achievements left.
Ah, the first roach of the dungeon!
A clean kill!  This job's gonna turn out great, I just know it!
You have found a secret room!
Find and conquer them all to gain access to a special master challenge area.
I coulda cleared those roaches without hiding in the alcove, but I feel lazy today.
All by himself too... that means I could be chasing him all over the room.
Wraithwings, unlike roaches, run away from Beethro and try to keep themselves at a distance of five tiles.
They are not as shy in bigger numbers, and won't hesitate to attack if they surround their prey.
That queen'll make tons of new roaches by the time I get to the orb and back!
Hmmm... can I kill off those queens before they dump eggs?
I'm sure there was a cleaner way to take out these roach queens.
Now THAT was a fine piece of smitemitery.
I know I coulda cleared this room without being invisible, but it was still fun.
That wasn't so hard... I wonder why that potion is there?
Whew!  Now those queens won't lay their eggs unless I'm close to them!
That was a bit rough, but nothing a good delver like me can't handle!
Ha!  Nothing's too tough for this delver!
Yikes!  I think I need the potion this time!
I coulda opened all the doors sooner than this.
No prisoners left? This is gonna be a lonely job with no one to talk to...
This looks dangerous... some kind of trap...
Wow!  Somebody shoulda been here to see me.
I coulda cleared this room without going back to the entrance hallway.
Why is it that dropping every trapdoor makes a room look better?
Holy Hoobuffins! Maybe there is such a thing as too many mimics!
Another secret chamber where everyone but me least expects it.

What will Beethro face next? Will the dangers become more hazardous? Will he manage to clean up the whole of King Dugan's Dungeon and finally get paid?

Congratulations!

You have completed the first episode King Dugan's Dungeon Lite. Did you enjoy the experience?

The last level left Beethro sweating. "I guess this is going to be hard work after all." Fortunately, there was a cool breeze coming from the next level.
Beethro left the tutorial floor rich with new knowledge.
Beethro came back to finish the proper smiting business he was hired to do.

Beethro stumbled up and down a series of poorly-lit staircases. "This is a safety hazard and there aren't even any roaches in here! Someone oughta at least put a handrail or s-" thought Beethro right before he fell twelve flights and knocked himself out for a solid hour. After dreaming horrible, horrible dreams about eyeball pudding, Beethro groggily awakened in a room. "Gob! Would it be so hard to have these places be on the map for once?"
Perhaps the level architect was trying too hard to make his point, whatever that point was. In any case, you can be thankful that there are no other levels in Dugan's Dungeon like this one.

As Beethro climbed down the stairs he heard a loud hissing. As a seasoned professional, he knew instantly what it was, but was still startled by the sheer volume. "Jeebus! How many of those nasty things are down there?"
Some monsters are cunning and lethal, and others are just a horrible pain to clean up after.

Beethro descended the stairs only to find himself in an uncharted corridor...

He won't get paid for clean-up here, but his professional honor urges him onward.
I hope you left yourself a path back.

This is a Master Door.
It will open when you have finished the last level and also conquered all secret rooms.
I didn't think you'd figure that last one out.

Okay, I admit it's not EXACTLY the same thing as light cycles.

-Erik
You might find it useful that Shift+Wait waits until the next spawn.

To the feeble-minded, turn back!  This room can only be completed by a master intellect.
(This room is not required.)
Feel free to play with it a bit.
Any blob that is not at least 2 tiles wide and high is unstable and will break apart into tar babies.
The living tar can only be damaged on flat edges.
A wise man will clear the northern room before following this corridor.
Clear south and west passages before continuing this way to avoid redundant backtracking.
Well now! Besides perhaps a couple of achievements, you should be finished with everything in the game.
Please accept my most sincere congratulations, you have achieved quite a feat!

Historical Note:
The original Flash version of the game had each episode released as a separate game - the tutorial was aimed at people starting their adventure with later episodes.
You can move diagonally even through very narrow corridors.
Ay, look at all those evil eyes!
Ah!  It still creeps me out when one of those things wakes up!
Clearing this place without any of those doors opening would be something to brag about.
Ha! Sloppy dungeon design, putting in unnecessary orbs like that!
Visit it if you haven't played this game before.
Dugan had better pay me for each of these rooms.
Those eyes coulda been smote proper without any turns.  Believe it!
Ha! Now that's efficiency! Wait 'til I tell the Smitemaster's Guild about that feat!
My blade won't scrape one scratch off that squirmy fellow.
But just lead him to a dead end, and I'll be rid of him.
Jeebus!  The serpent must be about one thousand, four hundred and forty-five feet long!
But my contract says I'm not obliged to deal with any monster longer than one thousand, four hundred and forty-four.
Could just let this room be.
Better be careful here... I can't get through if the tar clogs up that passage!
Tar mothers, too?  Why, why, why...?
Every thirty turns tar mothers will make the tar grow by one tile in each direction.
It is relatively safe to be surrounded by growing tar, but you have to watch out for tar babies which might spawn during the growth.
Good. At this rate, we'll be done mapping the level in a few minutes.
Do you hear that? It's the tar authority! We must hide!
Aaargh! I almost dropped the map!
Wait! Is the map facing the right way up?
This room... it looks... familiar... somehow...
It makes me feel... angry... and frustrated!
Rats... I hope there aren't any sneaky tricks, like rooms hidden behind a secret wall somewhere!
Oh gob... this room is gonna give me nightmares...
Your objective in DROD is to clear each level of all monsters.
Hit the roach with your sword to kill it.
All keys can be remapped from within game options.
Those without CaravelNet subscriptions won't have their scores stored in the leaderboard but will know what place they would have attained.
Click around to see what orbs do and what the evil eyes see.
This potion will allow you to place a mimic. Mimics copy every move you make and they move immediately after you, but before monsters.
Place the mimic at the tile marked with a checkpoint below. Use it to drop all trapdoors and the red gate will open.
Congratulations, you have completed this room!
Now go hit the orb with your sword.
Orbs interact with doors in three ways - they can open, close, or toggle their state.
Click on the orb with the mouse to see which doors it affects, and in what way.

Tar was not something Beethro expected. Or wanted to encounter. But walking down the stairs to the ninth floor he knows one thing - he can't smell this slimy substance there. But what if there is something much worse waiting instead?

Congratulations!

You have completed the second episode King Dugan's Dungeon Lite. Did you have fun?

Beethro sat down on the steps for a break. He pulled three bottles out of his pack. The ten-cup bottle was filled with refreshing leaf juice, and the other two bottles, which were in two-cup and five-cup sizes, were empty. Beethro wanted to drink exactly four cups of leaf juice in one uninterrupted gulp. He started messing around with the cups, pouring juice from one to another and back, but after a while gave up. "This is too much work!  Forget it!"
Beethro left the tutorial floor rich with new knowledge.
As many experienced dungeon exterminators know, beneath dwell some beasties that are able to blend into their surroundings.
Catching a glimpse of the room ahead, Beethro grunted in disapproval. "I don't know how, but the tar always ends up that way, and I hate it."
Beethro came back to finish the proper smiting business he was hired to do.

Again, Beethro heard loud hissing below, and knew to expect serpents. But this time the sound was slightly different, and he stopped a moment to listen and judge what lay ahead. "Good Gob! Those slitherbags must've been down there a gawdawful long time, with some big meals along the way."

Beethro descended the stairs only to find himself in an uncharted corridor...

He won't get paid for clean-up here, but his professional honor urges him onward.
Are you sure you are doing them in the correct order?
Invisibly evil spiders lurk on this level. Beware, for they are hard to see.
Psst... This passage takes you to the stairs. You might want to clear all other rooms before going there!
If a serpent moves west and it prefers horizontal movement, step to the east of its head to force it to move north.
It works the same vertically, but then the snake prefers eastward movement.
Your clock tells you which direction snakes currently prefer. This will help you to control these erratic creatures.
Getting here is a fabulous feat!

Original 13th Level
Visit each room at least once (%count% / 56)
"I probably ought to have skipped past this level, but a contract is a contract. Where'd I put those bread crumbs?" -Beethro
Beethro came back to finish the proper smiting business he was hired to do.
On this level, you'll finally meet some folks with a healthy respect for your blade.

This level is like the time you mowed the lawn and had exactly the amount of gas needed to finish, but then you screwed up, and had to go buy some more gas. And there was a big serpent at the gas station, and you wanted to go in to pay the attendant, but the front door was locked, so you drank a mimic potion to get in, and then the roaches...

Well, I guess the metaphor breaks down.
These roaches need an authority figure to guide them. Someone with charisma and character. Someone like you!
Beethro descended the stairs only to find himself in an uncharted corridor...
Beethro ran away from the challenge like a little, scrawny kitten.
Proud of his achievement, but a whole lot less sane, Beethro emerged from the infamous 13th level of King Dugan's Dungeon.
Beethro descended into the mystical set of deadly, pointless corridors.

Due to the difference in room size between the original DROD and this version some small adjustments were made to make things work.
Specifically some orb connections were changed, broken walls were added, closed gates were opened and the room with the stairs was slightly modified.
Hoo boy, no simple plow here. Let's plan the footwork ahead before I get moving.
Ahh...nothing satisfies like the sweet sight of no tar at all!
Look at that...not a single wall destroyed!
Bah...looks like I need to keep this goblin alive long enough to remove that serpent up there for me.
No helpings from me! You cuts me up, I know it--don't matter now or later.
Don't act all brave. Because I know goblins aren't brave.
No, No, No! Keeps pointy thing away!
You're thinking you'll sneak behind when I'm not looking. Yeah.
Look, you'd do the same in my place!
That's nasty business. Hope I don't have to do that again!
Rest there a bit while I open the passage, goblin.
(I probably didn't need to lock him up there...but better safe than sorry!)
Greb! One measly little roachie I've gotta squish.
Brilliant! Sometimes I even impress myself.
Now to get out of here...
Hmm...which way did I come in again?

The last four floors were a real pain for Beethro with the tar, the doors, the roaches... As he descended the stairs he smelled more of the blue goo which made him cringe but in the very far back of his head something told him that there is even worse danger ahead of him...

Beethro pulled out the three bottles again (10-cups full, 2-cups empty, 5-cups empty). "How am I going to get my four-cup swig?" He poured from the first into the second. He poured from the second into the third. He poured from the first into the second. He poured from the second into the third, but accidentally spilled a cup. With a sigh, he poured the remaining leaf juice back into the first bottle.

Beethro was going to start again, but then he noticed he was surrounded on all sides by living tar! It had grown around him during the drink preparation. "By Munbo! Can't a fellow settle down for just a moment?"

In Beethro's world, the number "18" is considered unlucky. Most dungeons are built without an eighteenth level. Of course, all levels of a dungeon are fairly unlucky to begin with, so maybe it doesn't matter that much.

"I've got that toasty 72-percent-done feeling. What's next?"
-Beethro

Question: You are starving to death, with no hope to find food in time. But you do have a mimic potion. Would you make a mimic, kill the mimic, and eat an exact copy of yourself to survive?

These are the kinds of questions a dungeon exterminator must answer every working day of his life.

You're probably the sort that uses people when it's convenient, and gets rid of them afterward.

I bet you are.

We'll see!
"Wow, I didn't expect to find a whole city down here. Good deal! Maybe they've got a restroom somewhere." -Beethro
Beethro came back to finish the proper smiting business he was hired to do.

"There better not be more than 25 levels to this place. That's plenty big enough, and all I'm down for in the contract," said Beethro as he arrived on the final level of Dugan's Dungeon. Just a short distance in front of him was a small man holding a mallet.

Beethro called out, "Hey there, little buddy! How'd you end up so deep below?"
The man shook his mallet angrily and raced off.

"Hold up! I want to talk to you!" But he didn't stop.
Beethro descended the stairs only to find himself in an uncharted corridor...

Welcome to the subterranean town of Neatherville. The locals are always glad to have visitors.

-Neatherville Board of Tourism

The legend goes that a king of past grew tired of his annoying young son and jokingly suggested that the lad go play in the castle dungeons. Taking his father seriously, the boy wandered deep into the dungeon chambers and was never found again.

Was 'Neather that long-lost prince? Is there a way he could have avoided killing the curious fellow?

All Beethro knows is that there was no Twenty-Sixth floor - the final stairs ended with a wall. With no convenient elevator in sight he was forced to once again traverse the dungeon.

Congratulations!

That's the final episode of King Dugan's Dungeon Lite! Beethro did manage to retire as a delver and open his Roaster Roach Grill. Not for long though, as a number of years later he acquired a portable orb that could open the mysterious door on Tenth Level. You can explore that story in DROD: Journey to Rooted Hold!

Beethro had heard that a vault containing valuable treasures lay within the underground chambers of a long deserted palace.

Mostly the palace was over-run with roaches and contaminated with tarstuff, but there were rumours that some of the original defences still remained.

Maybe Beethro could find a secret way in...

[Author's note: 1N1W inspired by a similar room in Nightmare Dungeon by Doom]
Beethro returned from the Tutorial Level

Beethro could not believe his eyes.

Clearly the palace had resisted any invasion by the vermin that littered the upper floors.

Vast marble hallways stretched out in all directions, lined by bizarre statues.

However, a contingent of evil eyes remained on watch for intruders.

As Beethro descended the air became colder and colder.

Perhaps the previous owners kept a wine cellar down here?

When Beethro reached the bottom of the stairs he was met with an even more astonishing sight.

Beethro continued to descend.

He entered a complex of twisting tunnels and lost his way.
After descending another set of stairs he came out well beneath the palace in the sewer system. Clearly he'd gone too far down and would have to retrace his steps.

Unfortunately, the door to the stairwell slammed shut behind him.

Beethro stumbled upon a long-buried crypt, since forgotten about.

What secrets would he find within?

Beethro finally reached the underground vaults.

A team of goblins and swarm of serpents still remained, guarding the treasure...

[Author's Note: 1N1E and 1S1E are inspired by similar rooms by Tim from the hold Advanced Concepts]
Here is a quick tutorial demonstrating most of the elements you will see in this, and other, holds and how they work.
Head up these stairs to go to a tutorial section.
Orbs in the bottom section each toggle the corresponding door in the top section.
This room is not required in order to exit this level but is required to drop the blue door.
The diagonal line of crumbly walls continues through the tar.

Snakes can't be killed with your sword, but only by being trapped in a dead end.

They cannot move diagonally or over force arrows or scrolls.

These are force arrows.

You cannot move across them counter to the direction they are pointing.

Click on each orb to see what it does.

Red: Closes yellow door

Green: Opens yellow door

Amber: Toggles yellow door between open and closed
Crumbly walls can be destroyed with your sword

Tar can be cut at its edges, but not at its corners.

If the width of a block of tar is reduced to 1 tile, tar babies are produced.

They move like roaches
Goblins are smarter than roaches - they can dodge around obstacles to get to you and run away from your sword.

The objective of each room is to clear all the monsters and exit.

When you clear all monsters, the green door will open.
Roach queens always run away from you
Roaches move directly towards you but can be blocked vertically or horizontally by walls or obstacles.

If you walk over a trapdoor, it will drop, revealing pit beneath which you cannot walk over.

If you drop all the trapdoors in a room, the red doors will drop.

Wraithwings can fly over pits.

Lone wraithwings always try  to stay 5 tiles away from you.

Multiple wraithwings can be more brave and can move towards you and attack.

Eyes do not move until you walk into their line of sight.

Then they wake up and move towards you as a roach does.

Stepping on a mimic potion allows you to place a mimic anywhere in the room (move with your mouse or direction keys, click or press "wait" to place).

Mimics will copy your every move.

Hint: Place in the chamber to the right.
Invisibility potions make you invisible to all monsters outside of a 5x5 square around you.
Stepping on a second invisibility potion reverses the effect of the first.
If there is no way of getting to you that the brain can see, the monsters will move normally.
Note that mimics cannot be placed on arrows, trapdoors, scrolls or yellow doors.

Roach queens lay roach eggs every 30 turns.
They cannot lay eggs over trapdoors, scrolls, arrows or yellow doors (open or closed)

Roach eggs hatch into roaches.

Roach queens lay roach eggs every 30 turns.
They cannot lay eggs over trapdoors, scrolls, arrows or yellow doors (open or closed)

Roach eggs hatch into roaches after 5 turns.

The eyes in the tar are tar mothers.

A tar mother in the room causes the tar to expand every 30 turns. Tar does not expand over arrows or scrolls.

If tar expands into a one tile wide gap, a tar baby is formed..

The red monster in the centre of the room is a brain.

They don't move and can't kill you, but if there's one in the room, all the other monsters can form a path to you and move around obstacles to get to you.
Brains don't direct monsters over arrows or scrolls
Brains don't direct monsters over arrows or scrolls
Note that mimics cannot be placed on arrows, trapdoors, scrolls or yellow doors.

Now that you have descended the final flight of stairs from this episode you have a few options ahead of you. You can strive to Master or even Post-Master this hold! To do that you will need to clear all the secret rooms and find the master wall. You will now be able to see the number of secrets in each level on Restore screen to aid you in your hunt. Remember that you only ever need to clear each secret room once ever - there is no need to do it all in one save. Clear them all and the master wall will drop.

Or you can go back to the title screen, chose "Change Episode" and play a different hold. Or go to Caravel Games website and buy any of the commercial releases, download a demo to play other people's holds... So many options!

DROD was conceived by Erik Hermansen back in the '90s. It is largely known as a puzzle game in which you run around rooms in a dungeon, slaying monsters with a Really Big Sword. How does this work?  You will see for yourself as soon as you get around to playing the game.

  Flash DROD is a port of the original DROD game. It uses the media found in the newer DROD game engines that you can download to play on your computer from CaravelGames.com.

Thanks to integrated CaravelNet capabilities, besides just completing the puzzles, players can compete with each other for high scores by completing each room in the fewest moves possible.

  Your objective is to clear each level of King Dugan's Dungeon of monsters. This feat can be accomplished using only your Really Big Sword™ and your wits. Each room is a separate area that has to be cleared in a single session. Should you leave a room without completely clearing it, it will be restored to its initial state when you return.

Beethro Budkin strolled into the Grand Dining Chamber where King Dugan was finishing his massive morning meal.

  "Away, foul commoner! You disrupt my digestion with your poor hygiene!" bellowed the King, with bits of pork and potatoes erupting from his mouth.

  "But sir," protested Beethro, "you sent for me."

  The expression on the King's large face changed from anger to confusion to recognition to geniality in the space of two seconds.

  "I really should have had you come in sooner," said King Dugan. "It's unbelievable! You let your guards eat their meals down in the dungeon, they spread crumbs all over the place, and all of a sudden the place is just swarming with giant cockroaches, not to mention goblins, serpents, evil eyes, and other nasty things. It's really gotten out of hand."

  Beethro straightened with pride. "Not to fear. I am a trained professional from a long line of dungeon exterminators. I combine five generations of passed-down knowledge with the most state-of-the-art equipment to offer efficient extermination service at an affordable price."

  "What kind of equipment do you use?"

  "I've got a really big sword."

"Good! When can you start?"

  "As soon as we handle the details of payment. Here are my standard extermination fees. Just sign at the bottom." Beethro handed a contract to the King.

  "These prices are outrageous! Is the privilege of honorable service to the Crown worth nothing these days?"

  "I can leave."

  "No, no, no. We need that dungeon cleared so that the prisoners can receive their torture in a clean and safe environment."

  "Well, I'll give you a discount if you'll throw in a princess."

  "You're ugly and you smell bad. None of my daughters will have you!"

  Beethro shrugged. "Fair enough."

  The King signed at the bottom of the contract. "Right then. Let me show you to the entrance."

As he descended, Beethro reflected on the job he had taken. Dugan's Dungeon was exceptionally large and, going by the reports of past exterminators, ridiculously well suited to infestation. It had also been secretly expanded several times, to the dismay of the first person to clear it out, whose contract hadn't covered the possibility. (He'd only gotten paid for the parts he'd known about.)

  Some said sinister forces were behind the expansion. The legend went that a king of past grew tired of his annoying young son and jokingly suggested that the lad go play in the castle dungeons. Taking his father seriously, the boy wandered deep into the dungeon chambers and was never found again. It was said that he did not perish, but lived the rest of his life in the dungeons by preference; that becoming a master of his new habitat, he learned all of the secrets of the underground world and formed alliances with the monsters that dwelt there, setting them to work creating new passageways and breeding better specimens of monster. He named himself the 'Neather, and schemed to rise from the dungeons to claim the throne when his powers were able.

Beethro wasn't sure about all that. For starters, the royal throne wasn't what it had been, now that its power was mostly transferred to a parliament. Never mind the question of who would want to live underground, or how they'd befriend the creatures there, who weren't great conversationalists. But it was true that dungeons tended to be unnecessarily complicated and easily infested, and even sometimes grow without warning - no Dungeon Architect would say why, as a matter of honor - and this more than anything was what kept men like Beethro in work.

  Anyway, an exterminator had plenty of more practical concerns, like the prolific and man-sized dungeon roach. The important thing in Beethro's mind was that he ought to make enough money and dead monsters on this job to finally retire from this thankless trade and open a restaurant.

  "I'll call it 'Beethro's Roasted Roach Grill'!"

"Deadly Rooms of Death", now almost exclusively called DROD, was created by Erik Hermansen in the 90s. Initially released as a shareware title by Webfoot, later Erik got permission to release it on his own which ultimately led to release DROD: Architect's Edition which featured a level editor.

  The game had multiple sequels which expanded the number of elements in the game as well as lore: Journey to Rooted Hold (2005), The City Beneath (2007), Gunthro and the Epic Blunder (2012) and The Second Sky (2014). Tendry's Tale (2008) is a spinoff that features an RPG-like experience, usually called "Tower of the Sorcerer"-like. Beyond that multiple Smitemaster's Selections were released - official, canon holds that expand the lore.

  The history of this release starts in late 2011 when Maurycy Zarzycki first mailed Mike Rimer (current owner of the DROD IP) with a proof of concept showing that Flash is capable of supporting what he considered to be the most computationally-intensive part of DROD - pathfinding. At some point a decision was made to release the game in 6 episodes. Ultimately only 4 of those were released - first in 2012, last in 2014.

  The idea to port this project to JavaScript started in mid 2021, continued a little in early 2022 and then, finally, it was finished and open sourced in mid 2025.
Click for quick introduction to how restore works.

Restoring works almost like saves in your favorite video games. The difference is that though you cannot save whenever you wish as the game autosaves when entering any unconquered room.

To restore to a previous state, first select a level from the list on the left, then choose a room on the minimap below. The minimap will grey out rooms which were not yet visited in the save. Those with a white background are conquered, those with a red one are not.

Later you can always load up your best state by clicking the "Select the farthest save" button.

Restore is the most useful if you want to improve your score for a room, search for secrets, or simply replay a favorite room.

You have chosen to go back to a previous state - some rooms will be restored to their unconquered state.

You can always restore to your most recent/best state by clicking "Select the farthest save".
Continue mastering this hold - use restore to find and clear all the secrets.

Lighted up achievements are acquired.
Greyed-out achievements which are not semi-transparent are "active". This means that in the current room you might be able to get or work toward this achievement (but not always, so read the achievement descriptions carefully). Do note that some achievements may be active in all or most rooms in the game.
